fields.headline: Schäuble urges calm on financial transaction tax after Cameron attack - as it happened
fields.body:
8.07pm BST

Closing summary

That's the lot for today. Here's a brief round-up of the main events, with links to the key points in the liveblog.

• Germany's finance minister, Wolfgang Schäuble, moved to calm the row between the EU and the UK over plans for a eurozone financial transaction tax. Schäuble told a high-level conference in London that the FTT could be years away, with many key decisions not taken yet (see 6.44pm).

• Schäuble's comments came after prime minister David Cameron attacked the plans for an FTT this morning. The British prime minister said they would hurt the EU as well as the City (see 10.23am), and drive business overseas.

• And Boris Johnson banged the drum for UK exports. From selling cake to Paris to sending Piers Morgan to America (no need to thank us, US readers) (see 1.58pm for the whole tub-thumping performance)

• In the currency markets, the yen fell through the ¥100 mark against the US dollar. (see 7.03pm onwards)

• In the eurozone, there was fresh unemployment misery. The jobless rate in Portugal hit a new record high, while youth unemployment in Greece jumped over the 60% mark for the first time (see 11.23am)

• In Spain, students and teachers held a general strike to oppose the government's plans to cut education spending. (see 4.37pm for photos)

• And Spain's industrial production fell for the 19th month in a row (see 9.02pm)

• But there were encouraging signs for the UK economy. Industrial production was stronger than expected (see 9.41am onwards) and independent forecasters at NIESR predicted that GDP rose by 0.8% in the last three months (see 3.18pm)

• The Bank of England voted to leave interest rates and the UK quantitative easing programme unchanged (see 12.02pm onwards)

Thanks for reading. We'll be back tomorrow. Goodnight!

7.47pm BST

Kit Juckes, Société Générale's experienced currency expert, says today's yen selloff shows that the foreign exchange market can be 'bonkers' sometimes:

Can't argue with his last point :)

Updated at 7.48pm BST

7.23pm BST

The Financial Times points out that the dollar has been ralling today since upbeat weekly jobs data was released, helping it into triple-figure territory against the yen.

The US dollar broke through the Y100 against the Japanese yen for the first time in four years amid positive signs on the US economy, after jobless claims by Americans hit their lowest level in more than five years.

The dollar index, which weighs the US currency against a basket of major counterparts, rose 0.4 per cent after figures showed that initial claims for unemployment benefits hit their lowest level last week since January 2008

7.17pm BST

This latest weakening of the yen against the dollar follows the concerted efforts by Tokyo to stimulate its economy through aggressive monetary easing.

OK, 100 is just a number. But as the FT's currency correspondent, Alice Ross, points out (see previous post), it's also a 'resistance level', so the dollar could well push higher in coming days.

The timing is also interesting -- with G7 finance ministers starting their two-day meeting on Friday.

Insiders have suggested that we don't hear any dramatic talk about currency wars from the G7, but behind the scenes the foreign exchange issues will definitely be discussed.

Updated at 7.22pm BST

7.03pm BST

Dollar hits ¥100 mark

The Japanese yen just fell through the ¥100 to the dollar mark for the first time since April 2009.

Updated at 7.03pm BST

6.44pm BST

Schäuble's calming words on the FTT

Wolfgang Schäuble's comments on the financial transaction tax may be the most important line from this afternoon's panel session with Osborne, Lagarde and Flaherty at the global investment conference (highlights from 4.42pm)

Reuters has the full quotes, and here's their story:

Germany’s finance minister said a controversial plan by 11 eurozone countries to introduce a financial transaction tax was not an urgent matter and it could take a long time to be finalised.

"We are just beginning this discussion. It is not a major concern to be very frank," Wolfgang Schäuble said in response to a question about the planned tax at a conference."This year, next year...it’s not (a) major problem," he said.

The 11 countries who have signed up for the FTT could implement it from 2014. But Britain fears it will have a major impact on City firms, as a large slice of the total market for transactions conducted in euros takes place through London.

Britain, of course, has launched a legal challenge to the plan.

Schäuble's suggestion that final agreement is a long way away does look like an attempt to cool the issue. Hours earlier, David Cameron had launched a full-blooded attack the plan.

As I wrote this morning (see 10.23am), the UK PM told the global investment conference that:

Unless it [the FTT] is introduced all across the world it is a mistake for Europe.

Cameron added that Europe would not make the financial system fairer by simply forcing financial firms to relocate to Hong Kong, and pointed out that 40% of all EU financial services activity happens in the City.

Updated at 6.50pm BST

6.23pm BST

The student protests in Spain are continuing, with a march in Madrid tonight:

5.42pm BST

Honestly, who can you trust?

The global investment conference in London finished with a plea to the cream of world business leaders to kindly not pinch the iPads they'd been loaned for today.

The BBC's Fiona Bruce, who was hosting the event, wound it up by urging the audience:

Don't take those event iPads with you. Apparently last year, 40% of them went missing.

5.34pm BST

And that's the end of the session.

5.29pm BST

5.24pm BST

The pensions timebomb

An audience member asks what can be done about pensions costs. Should retirement ages be steadily raised, and raised, to lower future bills and make them easier to meet?

Chrisine Lagarde replies:

The issues of entitlement will haunt G7 members for a long time.

She adde that it's essential to reduce the rate of at which entitlement programme costs are rising, so they are "rebalanced relative to GDP", and anchored into the medium and long term".

Flaherty point out that you need to give your populations fair warning if pensions ares are being changed.

Schauble argues that the first priority is to battle youth unemployment, so build up a workforce who can pay the future bills.

And Osborne points out that raising pension ages can have a dramatic impact on fiscal calculations.

Updated at 5.26pm BST

5.21pm BST

5.20pm BST

Flaherty also weight in on the Financial Transaction tax, pointing out that there is not wide support for it among the G20, as it is a "tax on bank customers", who did not directly cause the financial crisis.

5.18pm BST

5.17pm BST

Schäuble also told the audience that Europe must devise new measures to address the youth unemployment crisis.

We must speed up on youth unemployment, or we will lose democratic support in some countries, he adds.

(worth remembering that, for all Greece's 'remarkable progress', its youth unemployment level has now risen over 60% - see 11.23am)

5.14pm BST

Interesting... Wolfgang Schäuble just suggested that the financial transaction tax should not be a 'major concern' in the coming months, saying it will be discussed at the G7 meeting.

Schäuble said there was a long way to go on the issue before final decisions are made. The future of the FTT was already looking uncertain following Britain's decision to launch a legal challenge.

Is Europe losing its enthusiasm for the FTT, or just keen to kick it into the long grass for a bit? Curious....

Updated at 5.14pm BST

5.08pm BST

Schäuble: Lack of confidence in eurozone has diminished

Wolfgang Schäuble tells the audience that Europe has made impressive progress in recent months.

The eurozone crisis wont be the main obstacle to growth in future, he declares, and points out that the total euro-area deficit has halved in the last three years.

The lack of confidence has diminished.

Schäuble cites to the lower bond yields for Spain and Italy, and also hailed Greece's efforts, saying it has enjoyed "remarkable" progress in the last few months.

Updated at 5.09pm BST

5.03pm BST

Key event

Jim Flaherty, Canada's finance minister, says that governments need to balance their efforts to cut deficits in the medium term with the need to maintain economic growth.

He argues that ministers must ensure "medium-term fiscal responsibility" in order to provide health and education services:

If government's can't get sound fiscal policies in place, they can't get anything else right either.

But at the same time, he adds, they can provide incentives to the economy, perhaps pro-trade programes or tax benefits to manufacturers, to keep growth in place.

Flaherty adds:

It's about striking the balance so that you have growth in the economy at a time when governments are moving in the right direction fiscally.

And despite recent decent economic growth, Flaherty admits he is "very cautious" about the future.

4.54pm BST

Christine Lagarde speaks next, repeating her recent warning that the world faces a "three-speed recovery", which could develop into a "three-speed economy"

The iMF chief also points to protectionism as a priority, arguing countries could encourage economic growth by tackling this issue.

4.51pm BST

Osborne also flagged up that the G7 meeting will consider monetary policy issues.

4.47pm BST

That's Mark Carney, of course, who takes over at the Bank of England this summer...

Updated at 4.48pm BST

4.47pm BST

Osborne: G7 must nurture the recovery

Osborne begins by telling the audience that the G7 finance ministers will be discussing ways to improve the performance of the world economy, when they meet in the UK on Friday and Saturday.

He cites a new US-EU trade deal as a key issue, and adds:

We'll also be talking about financial regulation, and some of the issue we face about regulating the global financial community.

Osborne adds:

The priority is to nurture the recovery and build on the stability seen in recent months.

Updated at 4.47pm BST

4.42pm BST

Osborne, Lagarde, Schauble, Flaherty panel begins

UK chancellor George Osborne, IMF chief Christine Lagarde, German finance minister Wolfgang Schauble and Jim Flaherty, the Canadian Minister of Finance, are holding a panel discussion now at the Global Investment conference in London NOW.

The live stream is here.

Updated at 4.42pm BST

4.37pm BST

Photos: Students and teachers strike in Spain

Students, teachers and parents in Spain have been holding a public education general strike against budget cuts today.

Thousands marched in Barcelona, while some classes were disrupted as people protested against the government's cost-cutting reform plans in education, which are part of its multi-billion euro austerity measures.

More details here.

Updated at 4.39pm BST

4.07pm BST

More Europe news - David Cameron faces a rebellion among his own MPs over his referendum plans.

Our political editor, Patrick Wintour, reports that Conservative MPs are planning to engineer a vote on the issue by tabling an amendment to the Queen's Speech next week

Patrick writes:

The move has the support of hardline Eurosceptics such as John Redwood, Peter Bone, Edward Leigh and David Davis.

It is normal practice for amendments to be tabled to the Queen's speech, but it is for the Speaker to decide whether to accept them. It is likely that the Speaker will accept this amendment, with a vote on Tuesday next week.

It is very unlikely the amendment will be passed, but a sizeable show of Eurosceptic strength would be taken as a sign that David Cameron is struggling to control the mood on his backbenches.

Worth watching Andrew Sparrow's ace Politics Live blog for more developments in the days ahead.

Also, Boris Johnson has helpfully weighed in on the issue. He told reporters at the sidelines of the global investment summit that Britain must be prepared to "walk away" from the EU, if Cameron can't cut a better deal

The Daily Telegraph's Louise Armitstead has the details:

The Mayor of London said that he has "always been narrowly in favour" of Britain staying in the EU and "particularly of protecting British interests in the single market", but said there was also a "real opportunity to get a better deal from Europe".

He backed David Cameron's efforts to renegotiate Britain's relationship with Europe.

However, he added: "It follows from our desire to have a renegotiation that we must also be prepared to say, OK, fair enough, we can't get the terms that are suitable, then we will walk away."

Here's the Telegraph's full story: Britain must be ready to 'walk away' from EU, says Boris Johnson

3.47pm BST

Troika: Ireland must try harder on unemployment

Back in the eurozone, and Ireland's international lenders have warned that the country needs to do more to stimulate employment.

Following its latest mission to Ireland, the Troika reported that its bailout plan "remains on track". However, the labour market still has significant structural problems, it said.

The Troika (the IMF/ECB/EU) also bluntly criticised Ireland's banks for not cleaning up their books faster.

Here's the key lines from the Troika's statement:

After a disappointingly slow start, banks are working towards meeting ambitious targets to ensure a durable reduction in mortgage arrears and the authorities will need to monitor this process closely. Further progress by banks in resolving unsustainable small and medium-sized enterprises debts is needed to help bolster job creation.

While a pick-up in growth is needed to meaningfully reduce high unemployment, further policy efforts are important to address its increasingly structural nature. Further progress in enhancing engagement with the unemployed, including through the continued rollout of Intreo offices (which provide a single point of contact for all employment and income supports) and a redeployment of case workers, will ensure an even quality of activation and training services throughout the country.

The significant progress Ireland has made in recovering lost competitiveness in recent years should be continued through opening up competition in sheltered sectors such as legal services. Concluding disposal of state assets can support job-creating investment projects.

3.18pm BST

NIESR: UK GDP rose by 0.8% in Feb-April

Just in: Britain's economic recovery picked up pace in the last three months, according to the latest estimate of UK GDP from the National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR).

NIESR has estimated that UK GDP increased by 0.8% in the February-April period. If accurate, that shows that growth accelerated last month (as GDP grew by 0.3% in January-March).

That follows better-than-expected industrial production data this morning (see 9.41am).

City analysts and traders are encouraged by the data -- and reckon it strengthens the government's hand as talks with the International Monetary Fund begin.

1.58pm BST

Boris: Why London is the best city in the world

The London Mayor ends his speech with a display of classic Boris, challenging "mes amis" in the audience to dispute that London is the best city in the world.

Johnson stole the show by arguing that London offers a better quality of life. Here's the best bits:

We have a crime rate that has been consistently falling, a murder rate one fifth of New York, we have more green space than any other European city, a fantastic banker-funded bike hire scheme, the cleanest greenest new bus in the whole of Europe which we are shortly to export around the world.

We are planting tens of thosands of trees.

We have more musems than Paris, and free museums at that. We have twice as many book stores in London than New York - no wonder we have a fifth of the murder rate.

We have less rainfall than Rome -- I can't believe that statistic. We certainly have more theatres than either New York or Paris, and in a statistic I'm prepared personally to verify I'm told we have more Michelin-starred restaurants than Paris.

We have the right timezone, the right language

We are so faithful to the rule of law in this city that we lock up our MPs for trying to pass their speeding points to their wives. That is why people have faith in London.

Boris's broad point is that London is a global cross roads of export:

We export tea from the London borough of Sutton to China, we export bicycles made in Chiswick to Holland, cake to France, sand to Saudi Arabia.

We've exported the British museum to Abu Dhabi. Gordon Ramsey to Doha. We've exported David Beckham - we don't just import footballers, we export them - to Paris Saint-Germain where I understand he's doing very well, and we have send Piers Morgan to America.

That last 'export' got the biggest chortle.

Updated at 2.10pm BST

1.40pm BST

Indeed, Boris went on to argue that a new, four-runway airport in the London Estuary would revolutise the City, alongside other infrastructure developments.

You can easily invision a new hub in East London, competing with Rotterdam and taking business back from Rotterdam, and entrenching London's position as the natural trading capital of Europe.

Updated at 1.43pm BST

1.32pm BST

Boris also touched on one of his favourite subjects, London's airport capacity. And he says Heathrow cannot be expanded.

I don't think for a moment that expanding Heathrow is the answer.

Johnson adds that one-third of all people in Europe who suffer from airport noise polution live around Heathrow. There must be a "better solution" he adds.

The controversial Boris Island, perhaps?

Updated at 1.39pm BST

1.28pm BST

Boris Johnson, echoing David Cameron this morning, said it was important not to hurt the City, saying it provides £63bn in tax for the rest of the UK.

1.26pm BST

Boris: We need more apprentices

Boris Johnson is speaking at the Global Investment Conference in London, and urging business leaders to do more to create apprenticeship places.

The London mayor says that 100,000 places have been created recently, but this needs to rise to 250,000 in the next four years.

Johnson also touches on the issue of immigration, saying Britain needs a better visa system - and warning that it would be a mistake to block talented migrants.

I don't believe we will be helping young people in this city if we close markets to talented people from overseas, any more than we'd help football if we closed it to Nani or [Robin] Van Persie.

Updated at 1.26pm BST

12.44pm BST

Robin Hood campaign hits back at PM

The Robin Hood campaign has criticised David Cameron for attacking the EU financial transaction tax and claiming it would drive bankers out of Europe (see 10.23am)

In a statement, spokesman David Hillman said:

By lashing out at the Financial Transaction Tax Cameron has once again proven he's batting for the interests of the Square Mile and not for the interests of Britain as a whole." 

It's disingenuous of Cameron to claim FTTs will cause bankers to flee when this is clearly not the case with the UK's own stamp duty on shares. It raises the Exchequer around £3 billion a year and it makes no difference whether those trades take place in London, Hong Kong or Tokyo. 

Instead of repeating the lines of bank lobbyists the Government should give a proper justification for why they are refusing to tax the banks more and are cutting people's services instead.

12.41pm BST

Business leaders cheer Cameron's praise for the City

David Cameron's speech this morning was well received by the top business people in the audience, reports our economics correspondent Phillip Inman.

Phillip writes:

David Cameron's speech to the Global Investment conference went down well with delegates from City institutions after he praised the financial services industry and was happy to boast that London was a leading financial centre.

Delegates chatting to me in the coffee break after the prime minister's speech said there was a distinct change in tone from the previous year's conference when the financial sector was barely mentioned.

If you missed David Cameron's speech, you can now rewind the live feed.

A photo of David Cameron addressing the Global Investment Conference in London today:

In the eurozone, Portuguese unemployment has hit a new record high, underlining the labour force crisis raging in the eurozone periphery.

The total jobless rate hit 17.7% in the first three months of 2013, up from 16.9% in the last quarter of 2012.

Portugal's youth jobless rate also jumped, to 42%.

This is what David Cameron was referring to this morning, when he spoke of "stratospheric" levels of unemployment in parts of the Eurozone.

Greece's youth unemployment also hit a new record high of 64% in February, data released this morning data showed. That's up from 59.6% in January, and the first time it's been over the 60% mark.

Here's some early reaction to David Cameron's speech (see 10.11am onwards) from Twitter:

Some pessimists "say there is no prospect of reforming the European Union, you simply have to leave. I think they are wrong.. I think it is possible to change and reform this organisation.

10.40am BST

David Cameron went on to warn that the "stratospheric levels of unemployment in countries like Spain" are driving a debate about the future of the Europen Union.

And he sticks to his position that Britain should renegotiate its relationship with the EU and then hold a referendum.

First we must reform the European Union, then give Britain the choice if it wants to be part of it, Cameron argues.

No word on if the PM is considering bringing the referendum forwards, following the success of the UK Independence Party in last week's local council elections.

(Reuters has its own webfeed here)

Updated at 10.41am BST

10.34am BST

Cameron, who promised "less of a speech, more of a download"*, defends Britain's fiscal plans:

We need to get deficit down. We are not doing it at an irresponsible pace. We’re doing it at a sensible, measured pace.

The PM was explaining the key reasons why firms should invest in the UK - and the first one he cited is the City.

It's clear that this is an industry where we have a massive advantage...we should be proud of that.

We shouldn't spend our time in politics bashing banks and financial institutions.

webTitle: Morrisons says it can launch successful online business without Ocado

fields.standfirst: UK's fourth largest supermarket has been in talks for months to buy Ocado software in bid to catch up with rivals
fields.body:
Morrisons does not need a deal with Ocado for its online groceries business to successfully launch next year, according to the supermarket's bosses.

The UK's fourth largest supermarket has been in discussions with the online grocer for at least four months to buy some of its software in its efforts to catch up with other retailers that already offer home deliveries of groceries.

But Morrisons' new finance director, Trevor Stain, said: "We are not dependent on Ocado to go online. What we've said is we're talking with Ocado, but we may nor may not work with them."

The comments come as the company reported a 1.8% fall in like-for-like sales, excluding fuel, for the three months to 5 May, although when new stores are included sales were up 0.6%.

Morrisons' chief executive, Dalton Philips, revealed the Bradford-based supermarket had benefited from being untainted by the horsemeat scandal due to its integrated supply chain, with fresh food sales performing particularly well.

Fresh fish sales were up 10.5%, fresh fruit and vegetables up 4% and beef up 2%.

Philips said: "The horsemeat scandal dominated the first half of the period. Customers were rightly concerned about the standard of beef.

"We remain very encouraged around the fresh format and horsegate has demonstrated how seriously the British consumer thinks about the integrity of their food."

However, he refused to be drawn on whether negotiations with Ocado were on track or behind schedule, saying only that there would not be an update until the autumn.

He said: "Ocado is a first rate online retailer. I think they've got the best online website for groceries in the UK."

Investors had hoped Morrisons would give more details or confirm a deal with Ocado during its quarterly update, however, they were left disappointed and shares in both suffered in early trading. Morrisons shares closed down 2.7% at 288p.

Ocado is also unlikely to give its own shareholders any more details on Friday when it holds its annual meeting behind closed doors, with journalists banned.

A statement from Morrisons said: "Our plans to launch our first online food operation by January 2014 are progressing. Discussions with Ocado, previously announced, continue and a further announcement will be made as appropriate."

Analysts and commentators warned that without Ocado's expertise Morrisons could struggle to get a foothold in the online market, which is one of the fastest growing areas in groceries.

Neil Saunders, managing director of retail consultancy Conlumino, said: "I think Morrisons can do it without Ocado, but the issue is without Ocado's expertise it is a lot more difficult because they are going to have to build a lot of infrastructure from the ground up and buy in the management expertise.

"I'm sure they have contingencies, but it would definitely be the preferred route. It's possible, but not preferable because it would cost a lot of money.

"Rolling out a national operation without Ocado would be very ambitious."

The online groceries market is worth around £5.6bn and expected to double by 2017. On Wednesday, rival Sainsbury's revealed online sales grew 20% last year to nearly £1bn.

Clive Black, retail analyst at Shore Capital, said he believes Morrisons can launch an online operation successfully without Ocado.

He said: "I'm gobsmacked they are even talking to Ocado. Why they can't just build a website and hire some van drivers is beyond me.

"It reflects poorly on Morrisons' self confidence that they don't think they can do it on their own."

He also warned that any deal could cause a rift between Ocado and Waitrose, which have an exclusivity agreement that runs until 2017.

Morrisons, which has been losing market share due, in part, to its lack of online business, said it will also continue expanding into convenience stores and plans to open 100 by the end of the year, focusing on London and the south-east.

webTitle: Save the Children teams up with GlaxoSmithKline

fields.bodyText: The international charity Save the Children is embarking on a partnership with a multinational drug company in a controversial move which the two organisations say is designed to save a million children's lives. A decade ago, Save the Children was among the development organisations lambasting GlaxoSmithKline, one of the world's biggest drug companies, for its high price tags on HIV drugs for the developing world. The initiative launched by the two organisations on Thursday in Kenya will see Save the Children with a seat on the R&D board, advising on new products for the poorest countries, while GSK also pays for the training of more healthcare workers who will dispense medicines and give vaccines. Save the Children's chief executive Justin Forsyth, at the launch in Kenya with GSK's chief executive Sir Andrew Witty, described it as "a ground breaking partnership" which "involves both organisations working in genuinely new ways to save the lives of a million children". In the past, he acknowledged, Save the Children would not readily have jumped into bed with a drug company. "Many years ago I used to campaign against GlaxoSmithKline and press them to lower Aids drugs prices, and we gave them quite a hard time, but GlaxoSmithKline has changed enormously and under Andrew's leadership is leading not just the pharmaceutical sector but actually the private sector in terms of setting a standard for how a company moves beyond just corporate responsibility and philanthropy to how its core business can be transformative in terms of children," he told the Guardian. The two organisations say this is a novel concept, however, which breaks the mould of wealthy corporation salvaging its conscience by handing over money to charity. GSK will be reformulating some of its existing products to help save babies' lives. An antiseptic used in GSK's Corsodyl mouthwash in Europe and America called chlorhexidine will be turned into a product which can be used to clean the stump of the umbilical cord of a newborn baby, which can prevent life-threatening infection. The company will speed up the development of a child-friendly soluble powder antibiotic against pneumonia, in dose-sized packs. They will explore possibilities for an alternative product where milk and safe water are not readily available. There will be training for new healthcare workers in the poorest communities who can vaccinate babies and give essential medicines to children and advice to families. The initial focus for the partnership will be two countries – Kenya, where GSK has a significant market, and the Democratic Republic of Congo, where it does not but has already been supporting Save the Children in training health and community workers. Forsyth said: "I think the real big question we asked going into this partnership with wide open eyes was firstly how much of an impact it could have for children – and I think it's enormous – and secondly do we believe in each other's integrity and trust each other and I respect Andrew's leadership enormously." But "we don't agree on everything", he said and Save would still be willing to press GSK to lower its prices. Witty said it was "the next step on the journey that we've been going on over the last five years or so where we keep on incrementally – and in this case it is quite a decent step up – increasing the level of commitment we are giving to this agenda. What we're doing differently here is we're really trying to align the full business model of GSK to an on-the-ground delivery partner." GSK had "a whole portfolio of resources – mostly human, intellectual and research resources which we think can be lined up against some of the very specific needs which exist within child health within the developing world. "It's a way to really shorten the timeline it takes the world to go from need to figuring out how to solve it, find someone who's prepared to do it, generate an answer and eventually get it deployed. It takes way too long." The partnership is to run for five years and is worth £15m, £1m of which will be raised by GSK employees. It is a modest investment relative to the multinational's sales of $44bn in 2011, which generated a net profit of nearly $9bn. Witty, since taking over at GSK, has made clear his determination to help developing world populations, for instance by reinvesting locally 20% of any profits made in poor countries. But some other aid organisations still consider GSK's concessions have not gone far enough. Rohit Malpani, director of policy and analysis at Médecins Sans Frontières' access to medicines campaign, said the success of the partnership would depend on GSK changing business practices that "have undermined access to medicines across the developing world". There are pressing question for GSK to answer, he said. "Will they price their existing and pipeline HIV drugs affordably in all developing countries, or will developing countries be paying excessive prices? Will GSK grant MSF and other humanitarian organisations sustainable access to discounted prices already provided to GAVI so that we can vaccinate children against pneumoccocal disease?" he asked. Mohga Kamal-Yanni, senior policy adviser at Oxfam, welcomed GSK's commitment to training more healthworkers, but questioned whether it would be sustainable. "Who is going to pay them?" she asked. "The big problem for healthworkers is the lack of salary, especially in remote areas."

webTitle: ENRC loses ground after update and reports of broker resignations, but FTSE climbs again

fields.standfirst: Controversial mining group says iron ore extraction hit by harsh winter as investors wait for probe and bid news
fields.body:
Controversial Kazakh miner Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation fell 4% after new reports surfaced that its corporate brokers had resigned and it warned of a decline in revenues.

The company - whose founding oligarchs are considering a bid and which also faces a Serious Fraud Office investigation into its African and Kazakh operations- said iron ore extraction fell 9.2% in the first quarter, below City expectations. It blamed a severe winter in Kazakhstan where temperatures dropped as low as -46 Celsius. So with weaker commodity prices, ENRC said revenues for the first three months were slightly below last year's level. On a conference call where the company refused to take questions, chief executive Felix Vulis said:

I am sure that there are a number of questions that you have regarding events over the past weeks and I would dearly like to be able to answer them each in turn. However, as you will all know we find ourselves in the unique position of being in both an offer period and in the process of an official SFO inquiry relating to a number of historical allegations.

Meanwhile Deutsche Bank and Morgan Stanley, which have advised ENRC since its flotation in 2007, were said to have quit in recent days.

ENRC closed 11.9p lower at 291.5p.

But the overall market continued its recent rise, hitting yet another five and a half year high as the FTSE 100 climbed 9.26 points to 6592.74. Recent central bank action to boost the global economy again supported shares, with Korea the latest to cut rates. webTitle: Union anger as Lloyds announces compulsory redundancies at Southend

fields.bodyText: Unions accuse Lloyds Banking Group of taking a tougher stance on job cuts by imposing compulsory redundancies on 689 staff in a major banking centre in Southend, Essex. The bailed-out bank insisted the latest job cuts – which one union put at more than 1,400 staff in total – were part of a previously announced plan to axe 15,000 roles by the end of next year, bringing the total to around 40,000 since Lloyds rescued HBOS in 2008. Officials at the Lloyds Trade Union (LTU) said the bank was changing its approach by pressing ahead with compulsory job cuts. Steve Tatlow, assistant general secretary at the independent LTU, said: "There's a change in attitude … towards redundancies." The Unite union pointed out the return to profitability by the bank, which last week reported first quarter profits of £2bn compared with a loss in the same period a year earlier. While the LTU has worked with the Lloyds management, led by António Horta-Osório, on other job counts, Tatlow isplanning to mount a campaign to stop the closure of the Southend centre. He denied it was a "knee-jerk operation". "My trade union is opposing the bank's plans and is seeking to build a coalition of local interests from across the Southend community to pressurise Lloyds Banking Group into dropping its closure plans and to adopt alternative measures," he said. "These could achieve the same ends without condemning such large numbers of staff to compulsory redundancy nor inflicting such damage on the Southend local economy and community." The LTU argued that Lloyds could have picked a different centre for closure and that compulsory redundancies could have been reduced. It calculated that of the 940 jobs being lost in Southend, only around 75 would be transfered to Chelmsford, 18 miles away, while 176 temporary workers would be dismissed and 689 staff made compulsorily redundant. Lloyds insisted 850 jobs were being cut but that 275 roles were being created. It insisted it was continuing to use "natural turnover" and redeployment, and pointed out that a third of the staff who left in 2012 did so under compulsory reduction programmes. "Lloyds Banking Group is committed to working through these changes with employees in a careful and sensitive way. All affected employees have been briefed by their line manager today. The group's recognised unions Accord, Unite and the LTU were consulted prior to this announcement and will continue to be consulted," the bank said.

webTitle: Bank of England holds off on more quantitative easing

fields.standfirst: Monetary policy committee leaves interest rates unchanged at their record low of 0.5% and holds off from implementing a fresh round of QE
fields.body:
Bank of England policymakers have voted against boosting their £375bn quantitative easing programme, amid signs of a nascent economic recovery.

At the close of their monthly two-day policy meeting, the nine members of the monetary policy committee announced that they would leave interest rates unchanged at their record low of 0.5%, and refrain from implementing a fresh round of QE.

For the past three months, three MPC members, including the outgoing governor Sir Mervyn King, have advocated a £25bn extension of QE, but been outvoted by their colleagues, who are concerned that inflation remains well above the government's 2% target.

Howard Archer, of consultancy IHS Global Insight, said Thursday's vote may have been even closer.

"The Bank of England's decision to hold off from quantitative easing was once again likely the result of a tightly split vote. Indeed, it may even have been as close as 5-4," he said, adding that independent economist Martin Weale may have joined the dovish camp, "given his recent comments on more benign inflation developments resulting from lower oil and commodity prices as well as ongoing low earnings growth".

However, a no-change decision had been widely expected, after official figures showed that the economy expanded by 0.3% at the start of 2013, avoiding a "triple dip" recession. The latest data from the industrial sector, released on Thursday, showed that output increased by 0.2% in the first quarter.

Policymakers may also be waiting for firm evidence about the impact of the government's Funding-for-Lending Scheme (FLS), aimed at bringing down borrowing costs, before they take more action.

"With the FLS just extended in April and better-than-expected recent data, the MPC are probably comfortable waiting to see whether the improvement is sustained," said John Zhu, of HSBC.

King will explain the MPC's decision-making in more detail when he presents the Bank's quarterly inflation report, including updated forecasts for growth and inflation over the coming months, next Wednesday.

Next week's press conference will be the last before King gives way to Mark Carney, the Canadian hand-picked by George Obsorne to take over in Threadneedle Street, at the start of July.

Lee Hopley, chief economist at manufacturers' group the EEF, said: "Some signs of growth at the start of the year, together with some stabilisation of activity indicators in April will have been regarded as positive. But confidence that the underlying growth situation is improving will be fragile, leaving the possibility of more asset purchases on the table."

webTitle: SuperGroup sales rise despite poor weather and competitive market

fields.standfirst: Fashion retailer plans year of expansion as it develops presence in Europe
fields.body:
SuperGroup, the fashion retailer behind the Superdry brand, plans to expand in the current year, particularly in Europe, after a period of consolidation.

The group reported a rise in fourth quarter sales of 15.3% to £86.8m and a 14.7% increase over the year. Chief executive Julian Dunkerton said:

I am pleased the fourth quarter has seen a good trading performance against the backdrop of a challenging market given the extended period of cold weather in early spring.
After a year of consolidation, financial year 2014 will see the group start to move back towards historic levels of space growth as it develops its European presence.

During the quarter the company opened stores in France, Spain, Denmark, India and Lebanon. Analyst Bethany Hocking at Investec said:

This is a very resilient performance, in our view. Wholesale sales growth of 20% is strong, and should go some way to answer bears' concerns. Retail like for like growth of 5% is solid, albeit a few percentage points below consensus. Management are not expecting 2013 profit consensus of £51m to change. We remain happy buyers, even after the strong run of late – the future growth opportunities remain significant, in our view.

Jonathan Pritchard at Oriel Securities was also a buyer:

Difficult weather conditions and less trade clearance means that SuperGroup's retail sales growth is at the low end of expectations. 5% like for like still implies a major gain of market share and we have no concerns about the underlying strength of the brand.
The shares have run well into these figures... and any weakness on the back of one slightly slower quarter should be used as a buying opportunity.

The sharess have edged up 4p to 724p.

webTitle: UK industry sees March boost

fields.bodyText: Hopes have faded that the Bank of England could unleash a fresh round of quantitative easing at their policy meeting on Thursday after news that industrial output increased by a healthier-than-expected 0.7% in March. The Office for National Statistics said the overall rise in production over the month was driven by a 1.1% rise in manufacturing output, and a 2.4% jump in electricity and gas production, as shivering householders turned up the heating during the coldest March since 1962. Over the quarter, industrial production was 0.2% higher than in the final three months of last year, helped by a 4% increase in mining and quarrying, as North Sea oil production ramped up again after a major shutdown for maintenance at the end of 2012. Lee Hopley, chief economist of manufacturers' group the EEF, said: "Manufacturing looks to have had another good month in March with the data pointing to encouraging gains across the board, with almost all sectors posting some growth and on-going strength in transport and electrical equipment sectors. "However, a smooth recovery path is not assured as uncertainties in the external demand environment are likely to stay with us in the coming months." Analysts said the quarterly growth rate of industrial production was in line with the ONS's 0.3% estimate for the rise in overall GDP over the first quarter, which was made before complete data for March was available. With the nine members of the Bank's monetary policy committee due to complete their monthly meeting at noon, the industrial production figures were seen as fresh evidence that the UK economy is on the mend. Some members, including Sir Mervyn King, have recently argued for an increase in the £375bn quantitative easing programme, to help boost demand and kick-start recovery. However, City analysts said a new round of QE looked less likely after the positive industrial data. "UK factories stepped up a gear in March, boosting production for a second successive month. With surveys indicating that growth gained further momentum at the start of the second quarter, the encouraging data reduce the likelihood of policymakers seeing any immediate need to add more stimulus to the economy," said Chris Williamson, of Markit. Howard Archer, of consultancy IHS Global Insight, agreed. "There are signs that UK economic activity may at last be gaining a firmer footing, although the economy is far from out of the woods," he said. However, the ONS pointed out that despite the upturn in March, overall industrial output was 1.4% lower than during the same month in 2012.

webTitle: Barratt sees best housing market for five years as Help to Buy scheme boosts business

fields.standfirst: Builder reports rapid build up in use of government initiative unveiled in Budget but some analysts remain cautious
fields.body:
Government plans to boost the UK housing market - notably the Help to Buy scheme announced in the Budget - is already giving a lift to builders.

Barratt Developments reported a 9.7% increase in private reservations so far this year, has reduced debt from £167m to £100m and plans to recruit 600 graduates and apprentices over the next three years. It said:

The present market backdrop, in terms of consumer demand and mortgage supply, is the most positive we have seen for five years, and for 2013 the group expects to deliver a significant year on year improvement in operating profit.

The Help to Buy shared equity loan scheme launched on 1 April and Barratt said it had seen a rapid build up in use of the scheme, with around 400 reservations so far. Chief executive Mark Clare said:

Help to Buy has seen a strong start and we are investing in land and bringing it through planning to meet increasing consumer demand.

Anthony Codling at Jefferies issued a buy note and said:

Barratt is the third housebuilder to report a significant increase in reservation rates since the launch of Help to Buy. We remain pleasantly surprised at how quickly Help to Buy is actually helping people to buy.
We reiterate our buy rating on the shares. Following the announcement of Help to Buy and its quick implementation, we continue to see risks on the upside. We will, however, keep a watch on sales rates, which if left unchecked may lead to value being given away to homebuyers rather than shareholders.

And Robin Hardy at Peel Hunt saw risks to a possible reliance on government schemes:

Another positive trading update, reflecting that the impact of state intervention in the market is now exceptionally high, and we continue to have concerns about earnings quality as a result.
Barratt is set to gain perhaps the most from the Budget and, although we could see strong earnings per share growth through 2015, we see the valuation as stretched. On a more realistic mid-cycle PE basis, we cannot see fair value above 250p. We remain negative.

In the market Barratt has dipped 2.3p to 318o.2p.
